review_content: First off, Sapporo has the best designed beer cans I've seen. They are aesthetically pleasing, with nice contours and a heavy-duty feel in your hand. Even the pull tab is satisfying as it punctures the aluminum construction. Opening it seems to take the force of a trigger pull on a firearm. Does the can matter? Well, it might invite you to buy the beer as it does for me. But let me now focus on the liquid within. Appearance is light copper or clear amber. Carbonation quickly releases some white fizzy head which rapidly disappeared. Aroma is light cereal, grain, earthy with some minor floral notes. Basically, you're getting a lot of bread and biscuit malt with this one. I would have liked for it to be less watered down and more amped up with stronger malts. It's not bad, just don't be expecting Delirium Tremens quality. Style-wise, it is similar to DT as it is very malt-forward. The beer seems to emphasize its fine European ingredients, which I thought was odd for a Japanese beer company. Overall this is a nice sipper, with a light palate. If you enjoy biscuit malt beers you'll likely enjoy this offering from Sapporo. Purchased at Jax in Georgia.

Great lager. It’s wired in DC that I can’t find a place for a single beer instead of a pack. 
Take duck along with Sapporo reserve.
Pours a clear dark straw yellow with a foamy white head. Light lager flavor. Nothing special.

From the 650 ml. can stamped L1218H-1205FL.  It pours a nice looking, bright golden color with along lasting creamy white head and streaming carbonation.  The aroma brings out a barley grain sweetness with a little floral or grass underneath and a kind of pear quality.  Smooth, medium mouthfeel.  The taste is sweet and bready with a touch of floral hops to top it off. But I also find a buttery sensation.

Ar: Doughy malt, with an accent of moss and hay; dry crackers. Ap: Deep golden and clear; large white head with good retention, settling into a medium cap of fairly dense foam with some wavy patterns of lacing on the glass sides. T: Doughy fresh malt; a little toast; black licorice, slight mushroom earthiness, and grass; bitterness is low and very clean; a little minerality; cracker malt, chalk, and lemony grassiness on the finish. P: Medium-light body with high carbonation; dry finish. O: A quaffable lager; a bit more heft and body than many other macro lagers.

12 oz bottle apparently brewed in Canada. 

Pours clear amber: darker than normal for style; decent but short-lived white head. 

Aroma: grassy but a bit brighter than usual for style.

Flavor: reminiscent of a [low-hopped] German pilsner, but both sweeter and more floral. Less dank and grassy than usual for style.
650ml can, brewed in Vietnam. Typical pour, this is a sweetish vaguely citrus hoppy lager that is honestly much better than most pale lagers.
Poured from 22oz can. Gold with very frothy but short lived head. Light tasting with hints of apple juice.

No sé si me toco una cerveza con mal manejo posterior al adquirirla pero la carbonatación fue muy pobre, el aroma es desagradable (como cuero) y el sabor es penetrante,pero el retrogusto amargo ligero, buena textura.

Buena cerveza larger de las mejores, sabor fuerte con cuerpo, buen sabor excelente presentacion 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 oz. bottle. Pale yellow with a minimal white head. Aroma and taste of apple juice, corn, grains. Finish is thin and a bit sweet.
Poured from 22 oz can. This can is incredibly dense. Poured gold with white head. Aroma lager malts and sweet. Med carb and bod. Tastes full of grain min hop.

Hazy yellow-gold color with a small khaki head and poor retention. Minimal lacing. Flat mouthfeel. Clean, grainy euro-lager flavor with only minor skunk taste. Fairly pedestrian lager flavor, but nothing bad either.

Pours a thin golden with a small white head. The aroma is weak. I find light floral hops, cereal, grain, and corn. The taste has more going on, but not in a better way. Minor bitterness and with a heavy grain flavor. Some corn and earthy malt, and its a little skunky as well. Short and strong grainy finish. Light in body, and thin in texture. This is easily the worst Sapporo product I've found so far. It represents one of the many perils of rating beer.

DOC: 3/2/2017

2015 BJCP Category: 2A International Pale Lager


AROMA: Light sweet grainy malt without cereal notes. Minor presence floral/spicy hops. Clean fermentation. 10/12

APPEARANCE: Clear golden color; large bright white froth mostly dissipates, but does leave a bit of lacing. 3/3

FLAVOR: A moderate, firm amount of sweet grainy malt. Almost has a bit of a caramel flavor in the background. Palette becomes a bit more rustic and cracker-like on the departure. There is a low presence of spicy/earthy hops as it’s finishing with a slightly dry bitter aftertaste. Clean fermentation. Well-balanced and quite enjoyable. 18/20

MOUTHFEEL: Medium body and carbonation. More smooth and calm than effervescent. Has the refreshing quality of a pale lager with a clean aftertaste. Plenty of character for 5% ABV and possibly sessionable. 4/5

OVERALL IMPRESSION: Not the greatest beer in the world, but for the style it’s one of the best. This proves macro lagers can be enjoyable when brewed and served properly. 9/10

TOTAL SCORE: 44/50

Poured from 22 oz can. This can is incredibly dense. Poured gold with white head. Aroma lager malts and sweet. Med carb and bod. Tastes full of grain min hop.

DOC: 3/2/2017 2015 BJCP Category: 2A International Pale Lager…

24oz can, a really really thick one from Guelph that I can’t crush with my hand. Nose pretty lacking – a hint of malt wafting up, or perhaps imagined? Pour a brilliant and rich transparent golden, much nicer than is usual for this type of beer, hear is large and foamy eggshell. Taste lightly sweet with a medium and almost painfully hard bitterness, though not astringent, more like swallowing a rock. Medium-full body with malt, grass. Little bit of mineral, bit of hop prickle, very faint metal and floral. Would probably have again, mostly to have the can to prop up a leaning table. Seriously, buy it to check out the can. [2017.05.28: 1.9]
Big can at Yen in Fulshear. Clear pale golden with a big white head. Soft aroma of grain. Tastes grainy and lightly peppered. Crisp light bodied.
Aroma is relatively strong malts and fruit in the background. The flavor is malts, a hint of caramel, fruit and a mix of clean and mild/medium sweetness in the finish.
Bottle. Clear golden color, white coca cola head. Light pepper aroma. Taste is clean, crisp, peppery. OK.

Very light malt smell, taste is lightly bitter and quite malty....Good mouthfeel... Light bread taste..Fairly smooth...At inakaya with Nora, Ashley and John after new years..
X2 at inakaya for Richelle's going away party (work in Austria)
Yellow, small head, fruity aroma, caramel, toffee, bitter flavor, sourish, plums, weird, light bodied.

Can shared at a tasting at Max’ place. Thanks Excellent Little Brother! Clear gold with a white head. Sweet and a little papery aroma, sweet and papery taste. Light body, not enough carbonation, papery finish.

Can - no head at all, pretty flat - not sure if it's supposed to be like that? Nice medium copper color though, sweet cereal malt aroma and flavor, mild fruity hops, flat finish, ok overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can sample at a tasting at Max’s place. Thanks kerenmk. Yellow with a small white head. Aroma of oxidation, cardboard, grape juice. Sweetish flavor with graininess, cardboard, and a faint bitterish note in the finish. Light-bodied.
From a bottle. Really well balanced flavorful dry lager. Very smooth without seeming excessively watered down. Good bit of malt. Nice lager.
Let humlet, blød i smagen, ikke så skarp som fx en Tuborg. En del sødme i eftersmagen. Lidt kedelig, men god en varm dag på terassen.

Pours an amber from a can. Very little head, kind of expecting a little more. Slight biscuit aroma, maybe a tiny bit skunky. Flavor is really just a sweet malty graininess. Not bad, really not much of anything. Meh.

Tasted from bottle. Minimal aroma. Notes of rice and grains, some sweetness. Taste is very smooth. Really not much skunk compared to most lagers. Above average for pale lager. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
People are stupid. About as good as a standard lager can get. Very clean and easy to drink. Slight light lemon and herbal hops, excellent with food. All malt beer people talking about corn. lol

Dorado con transparencia, buena espuma sin retención. Malta maltoso moderado bajo, aroma a arroz moderado, lúpulo nulo. En boca dulzor propio de la malta, lúpulo de amargor moderado bajo, ligero metálico. Final seco y con ligero amargor, carbonatación baja, cuerpo bajo.

Poured from a 650 ML can into a pint glass at the World of Beer in Pooler, GA. The beer has a nice malt and grass smell. The beer is a fairly dark golden color with a small white head. Nice mild malt and grass flavor with a semi-dry finish.
Big 17oz can at Daikaya Ramen in DC. Pours a clear, deep gold with some frothy white head. Nose of corn, rice, yeast. Flavor is the same, lots of corn, some grain finally. Slick finish.
3 July 2015, can. Smiles like sweet rice lager. Thin body and mildly fizzy. A bit sweet, rice malt with a hint of bitterness. Decent n

Drank a can of this one yesterday. A nice darker coloring than normal, a somewhat watery smell and taste. Some bread and grass on the taste, some Tastes a little earthy too. Not a lot going on for the aftertaste, fades quickly.   It does have that pleasant dryness to the taste, and is palate cleansing, so it matches well with Japanese food especially sushi.  Very drinkable though, and quite refreshing. Also, you won’t feel the alcohol so that’s either good or bad depending.

Bottle pours a golden/orange with a medium white head. Aroma of corn, malt, barley, with a hint of vomit and ash tray. Bitter hops really jump on the palate, not in a good way, opening it up for corn and cardboard malt vomit. Ugh, I’d get more satisfaction drinking a stale beer with cigs in it.
Tap, gold pour, white head, nose is lacking, taste is some hops, decent overall

Canadian brewed 22oz can, consumed on 12th May 2015 in Southern California where it was bought. Disappointed to be honest, bland and uninteresting in my opinion. The clear yellow body had no head worthy of mention and although well carbonated on the palate it looked flat and sad, Slight grainy nose and taste with a mild sweetness from those grains, glad I shared the can with my Son-in-Law (who did not enjoy it either).

I got the Canadian product. It is a typical pale yellow lager with a thin white head and modest carbonation. The aroma is light and grassy. The taste is light, clean, and slightly sweet. The finish is clean and short and the overall impression is an unremarkable one, though the beer reminded me strongly of Royal Challenge.
bottle shared with josh at club w, aromais a mixyure of honey and socks, hazy orangish pour with white thin head, , taste is sugary weirdness, some fruit, meh

Clear Golden pour small quickly disappearing off-white head
sweet smooth and malty.
sweeter smoother finish than reg. supporo

regular sapporo is better drinking although this has smoother body
"an above average macro lager...but in the end still a macro lager. a little more flavorful and hoppy in the aroma than Sapparo premium, but still weakish. malt leaning aroma and thin flavor."

Can from old backlog notes. Pours a clear pale yellow color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have sweet grainy malts, corn, dusty, I don’t get the reserve as the regular beer is probably better.

The pour produces a tall white head over a deep golden body with excellent clarity. The head slowly fades and just keeps a small cap tight foam till the last sip. It also makes some cool lace pattern on the glass. It has a raw grain with a straw and light floral like hop bouquet. Overall it’s light, simple and very clean. The flavor profile has the same clean grain and straw/floral hop mix with a dry biscuity finish. Its light to body is refreshing and well carbonated.

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, K3012G bottle code. Pours fairly crystal clear bright gold color with a 1 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of lemon, cracker, biscuit, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of pale malt, earthy hop, and light yeast ester notes; with solid strength. Taste of lemon, cracker, biscuit, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Light earthy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, cracker, biscuit, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice balance and robustness of pale malt, earthy hops, and light yeast ester flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Flavors are very clean as well with no overly estery yeast notes. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and clean mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with no warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice pale lager style. Good balance and robustness of pale malt, earthy hops, and light yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.

Can.

A- Cereal, corn, malty, grassy.

A- Golden color, clear liquid, white head.

T- Corn, slightly sweet, malty, cereal, watery.

P- Light body, average texture, average carbonation, crisp finish.

O- Couldn’t tell much difference from the normal Sapporo. Still boring and just another lager.
Traditional nose and pale appearance, slightly more malty than the original Sapporo but still tastes like your usual Asian pale lager.-- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10
Can; clear gold with small white head; aroma-hay, cooked vegetables; taste-no sweetness, minimal bitterness, light, fizzy. Standard Asian Lager

Can 22 oz in Pompano Beach, FL Pours with a largish, foamy, off-white head covering a deep yellow body. Aroma is a bit of wheat and maybe a little corn, with a fruity note at the end. Ultra thin mouthfeel. A little bit spicy and metallicy. There is also an odd apple taste to the beer. Interesting Japanese lager.

22 oz can into tulip.

Appearance: pale golden in color. Massive foamy head with lacing. 

Aroma: sweet malts. Grains. 

Taste: Mildly sweet. Flavorless.

Palate: thin 

Overall. Beer from japan, I guess.

Location: Uchi - Houston, 12/9/13




Aroma: It has a light nose of pale malt, and some light hops


Appearance: It pours a clear gold color with a white head


Flavor: The taste is light and drinkable, similar to the nose, typical flavor for the style


Palate: The body is light, it has an alright mouthfeel, and a short finish


Overall Impression: 
Overall, this is a fine example of the style, but ceertainly no more than a mediocre beer.
Bottle. Golden pour with a good white head. Grain with some sweetness and spice. But no surupyness. Bigger than normal. Tastier but light enough to go with sashimi. Actually pretty good.

Well this is an "intriguing" premium lager, also is definitely better than average. Begins with an exceptional appearance, a solid gold color with a fluffy head and a great deal of lacing. Aroma is mild but distinctive, malty but also some floral sweetness. Taste likewise is somewhat subdued but a fresh and clean pale malty flavor. A full mouthfeel, although doesn't feel very carbonated despite the amount of lacing. Finishes smooth but also dry. Overall, a good pale lager, but nothing Japanese about it as far as I can tell, considering its made with all malt and imported European hops. A successful imitation of a quality European lager I suppose.

Btw i'm amused by the previous reviewers' fascination with the unusually large and durable cans this beer is packaged in.

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Appearance: pours a thin head that recedes quickly. Lots of streaming carbonation and bubbles clinging to the sides of the glass. Color is a deep golden. Mild lacing.

Aroma: rich aroma of toasted malt, a bit of grassiness and some hop spice. Very pleasant aroma.

Mouthfeel: slightly heavier than most lagers, has a fullness in the mouth feel, almost some wine like characteristics. Finish is dry.

Flavor: nice combination that mirrors the aroma. Toasted white bread, some grassy flavors, and some mild lingering hop bitterness.

22 oz / 650mL indestructible can into a pint glass. Served cold.

Aroma: Mild sour bread malt. Just a touch of hop.

Appearance: Clear dark gold body with a moderate foamy white head.

Taste: Moderate bready malt. Slight metallic twinge. No hop profile.

Palate: Light-medium body. Short finish.

Overall: Just a bready lager. Not bad, just nothing that stands out.
Draft at Nori Sushi. Golden pour with a ton of white head. Clean crisp refreshing lager. Wheat and grain taste. Can't tell this from regular.

22oz can poured into a shaker. Pours a clear dark gold with minimal head. Aroma is mostly grains with some very light herbal hops and a hint of muscat grapes. Taste is light bitter. Mostly grains with some woody herbal hops. Medium bodied with a relatively thin texture. Lively carbonation and a decently long finish.  Overall, not bad. Nothing super special but drinkable. Meh.

22 ounce can. Pours a clear golden color with a large foamy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of sweet malts, dust, cereal grains, tinny hops. The taste is toasted grain, cardboard, grassy hops, corny finish. Thin-Medium bodied. Meh.

March 6, 2013 - 22 ounce can from Randalls. Clear golden pour with big head that lasted a bit and spotty lacing.  Aroma was faint but some malt.  Taste was grainy and malty with a slight metallic finish.  If this is the Reserve, I can’t imagine what the regular is like, hahaha.

Big fucking canned @ home picked up at Argonaut for $2.99. Pours a clear burnt orange appearance with a fluffy, off white head. Somewhat herbal, woody hoppy, toasted malty aroma. There’s some hops in the flavor but there’s a dull, woody, sweet malty, lightly fruity, light white grape flavor. Not as good as the regular Sapporo.

Pours a very clear and pale yellow color. Barley malt is very evident in it’s scent hinting that this might have a cheap beer taste. The taste is mild and rather malty. Rather simple and nothing all that special considering it’s from Japan. Something new to try from a different country, but considering it’s taste...you could go with Pabst Blue Ribbon and not be missing much.

Bought simply because the can was so appealing at the top of the shelf. 22 oz can of Reserve was the same price as the regular version, so I went with the Reserve. Pours a very slightly hazy orange/yellow with a large force-carbonated head that recedes to nothing and leaves almost no lacing. Aroma is essentially non-existent. Taste is not too far from a standard American lager; tastes like it’s adjunct-laden even though it’s all-malt. Decent drinking, but way overpriced for what it is. Neat can, at least. Also note that although the company is Japanese, this is brewed in and imported from Canada.
Not bad. A little taste of grain and crisp finish. A little bitterness even, though tinged with chemical. Don’t remember seeing this while I lived in Japan. Big weird Sapporo can.

Serving: Can.  It pours a light gold color with a stark white head.  The nose is pretty light with a touch of grain and malt sweetness.  It’s crisp on the tongue but there isn’t much in the way of flavor.  A hint of grain, malt, and a touch of light honey sweetness balanced with a slight bitterness.  Light body with high carbonation and a clean finish.  Certainly not remarkable.

Can. Tan fizzy looking color. Smells sweet with hints of rice and malt. Weird aftertaste. Eh

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured into lager glass. Clear gold with pillow top head and great lacing. Smell of malts. Light taste that finishes clean. Its OK.
16.6 oz can Old Notes-Pours a clear golden with a nice white head. Aroma of corn, sweetness, and grain. Taste of the same. This light bodied brew is not too shabby. Well balanced and quite tasty.
Big can in West Long Branch, NJ. Bold golden body with puffy head. Corny, grainy and lemon nose. Taste is malty, wheat with some nice bitter notes. Enjoyable.
Can! Pours gold with a white head. Grainy, a little bit corny, but not too dirty. Really not that bad, some weird plasticy notes but otherwise comparatively clean.
Great bold strong flavor, love the bottle and appearance, havent ever seen this before,
Can. Pours clear light yellow amber, with a fizzy medium white head. Aroma is malty, with grain and sweet honey notes. Taste is mainly grain, with some malt and a little hop bitterness.

Bottle. Aroma of lager malts. Poured a boring piss yellow color with little to no top at all, and no lacing. Adjunct flavor, rice, pilsner malt. Clean and crisp on the palate. Not grainy. Overall, it’s a lager, nothing special

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a nice gold with a decent one inch white head that lasts.  Taste is of malt, grass, hay and some hops.  Slightly sweet.  Similar aroma.  Has a decent body, that is somewhat full.  The finish is a bit bitter and dry.  Easy to drink and rather enjoyable.  Not a bad beer.

22oz can-  Pours a clear golden color with a moderate head and no real lacing. Clean aroma of malt, fresh grain and just a bit of sweetness. Taste of malt and fresh grain with a mild sweetness. There is a very subtle bitterness and a dry finish. Light body, very crisp and smooth. Decent balance and a very clean feel. Nice beer that goes down very easy. Fairly bland but was still enjoyable. Compliments Japanese cuisine very well. Quite good for the style.
I think this beer has got real character to it. has a great emphasis on the malt and rice. no bitterness. pretty full palate.
Smells of hay, corn and maybe a bit of burnt hair.  Tastes maltier than expected.  Actually decent appearance, with some gold in the color.  Nice and smooth, maybe a little thin.

Poured from Sapporo’s signature bomber can, and as a result it has an aroma that’s bready malt and metallic. Looks a shade darker than most lagers, decent head to start at least. Cloying sweet start, flushes out to a dry hollow finish. Where many would have their beers medium rare, Japan’s lagers usually come well done. Overall a very drinkable and refreshing beer, but I wouldn’t write home about it...or did I just?
Tasted: Bottled 04/14/12. Light and crisp very little head. A slight sweet wheat taste. Nothing special light and refreshing. Had with sushi.

Pale golden copper hue. Thick foamy white head. Grainy alcohol nose. Smells like Old English or some crap. Really watery, nasty grain, light metal, light bodied, finishes with a real crappy bitterness.

Golden clear, no head. Smells of wheat bread and lager malts. Tasted like caramel infused lager malt, with some light tomato as well. Light and sweet, with a little more maltiness and body opposed to a typical macro.

Tasted from cool-looking fluted tall-boy can into a tulip glass. Poured a clear light amber color with huge white foam which quickly subsided leaving some lace. I didn’t taste it side-by-side with standard Sapporo, but as I recall, this one benefits from an all-malt recipe (free of typical rice/corn adjunct faults,) richer color, slightly more aroma hops, with a hint of caramel in the flavor. It still had a light body, spritzy carbonation, with a crisp, refeshing lager finish. Nothing too unique here, but definitely drinkable.
Very sweet smell and taste.  Clear.  No head.   Very drinkable.  I appreciate that the can can’t be destoryed.

The can is the best part of this. Otherwise, despite being all malt, it’s a macro lager. I’m guessing 6 row is used; really no malt flavor. Hops are light and there is a very feint sour tang to it. The good news is it is crisp and light. But that’s it. I’d rather drink Stella.
Pours a golden yellow color with aroma of malted corn.  Taste is clean corn notes with a mild light flavor.  A slight sweetness in the aftertaste, a decent malt beer.

Clear yellow colour with frothy white head. Faint corn and bread aroma. Taste is crisp, well balanced lager. Watery. I’m not sure what’s the difference between this and the regular Sapporo. A quality lager, but it’s still just a pale lager.
Bottle at a Japanese steakhouse - Pours cloudy light yellow with a foamy head. Has a light malt flavor and an average mouthfeel.

Sapporo Reserve has a thick, soapy, slightly off-white head, and a clear, yellow-golden appearance, with lots of streaming bubbles and pretty thick lacing. The aroma is standard lager- barley and water. Taste is sweet, bread, lightly-roasted barley, and a bit of hops for rounding purposes. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Sapporo Reserve finishes crisp, clean, refreshing, mild, and easy drinking. This is a lager the way it’s supposed to be, and it’s delicious. RJT
500 ml can. An uninspiring beer. Lots of corn and sweet pilsiner malts in both aroma and flavor. Bright gold in color. A very generic beer.
Gold color with a white head and some light lacing . Nose of  grassy hops and malt. Medium mouthfeel; Low carbonation. Flavor is lightly bitter and floral hops. Beats Bud by a mile.
500ml bottle in a lager glass.  Pours golden with a white head.  Aroma of pale malts and light hops.  Light texture.  Not terrible for a lager.

Houston, TX - 10.01.2011
Bottle

Just what you would expect from any mass produced lager. Not sure what makes it reserve. Always fun to get with sushi if you not a Sake fan. Drink slightly better than American lagers in my opinion.

What a surprise! This brew was much better than I had anticipated and has helped start the change in my mind as to the perceptions that I have towards certain beers from Asia! I truly enjoyed the maltiness of this brew! It looked so light but has a really good ‘chewy’ texture to it but it is nothing overbearing so don’t let that throw ya! This brew was very tasty too with flavors that were very well-blended. I will certainly be venturing more with Asian beers thanks to the likes of this one!
Detected a mild wheat aroma. Pours nice and clear golden yellow with active carbonation. Has a light sweetness and bitterness. Finishes nice without any unpleasant aftertaste. A nice brew.
Can from Trader Joe’s.  Better than the regular sapporo.  Flavor is cleaner.  Good carbonation.
22 oz can from Publix.  Pours golden in colour, with large white head.  Large carbonation.  Taste and aroma are slightly sweet, mild hops.  Not really that different than regular Sapporo.

Golden clear, no head.  Smells of wheat bread and lager malts.  Tasted like caramel infused lager malt, with some light butter as well.  Light and sweet, with a little more maltiness and body opposed to a typical macro.
Yellow, good head.  Decent amount of malt taste with some hops to it.   I wasn’t expecting it to be this good at all.

Bottle. Pours completely clear copper with a thin but solid white head and active carbonation. Aroma is a bit adjuncty but has some nice hay/straw qualities. Highly carbonated yet still flat on the tongue. Bland, very light mal tnotes. Finishes dry and spicy.
Overall not a bad tasting beer.  I did like the 22oz can.  It’s an above average beer, drinkable and enjoyable.  Doesn’t have a "bite" to it, which is what many probably expect from a beer.
Pours gold into a shaker. Bright white head with medium retention recedes to hug rim. Sweet bread aromas. Crisp then flat with bread and hay from front to back.
A little carbonation, almost no lace, nice gold color.  Semi-yawn, but nice can :).

Bottle. Golden, small and fully diminishing head. Light, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, faint grassy hoppyness and caramel, some alcohol. Body is light to medium, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, some alcohol, faint hoppyness. Finish is short, malty and dryish, some alcohol and caramel,faint hoppyness. Malty lager with alcohol in the flavor/finish.

Presentation: It was poured from a tall 22oz can into a mug. The can offers a very brief description but no freshness date or abv.

Appearance: The pour produces a tall white head over a deep golden body with excellent clarity. The head slowly fades and just keeps a small cap tight foam till the last sip. It also makes some cool lace pattern on the glass.

Smell: It has a raw grain with a straw and light floral like hop bouquet. Overall it’s light, simple and very clean.

Taste: The flavor profile has the same clean grain and straw/floral hop mix with a dry biscuity finish. Its light to body is refreshing and well carbonated.

Notes: It’s a good clean lager and an uplifting palate cleanser opposite my pineapple fried rice.

Appearance: clear straw with some gold mixed in. bubbly head disappears fast. Swirls with more bubbles which disappear equally fast, lingering only with a meager bubbly collar.


Nose: bright, masks aromas. Eventually dredge up bread crusts, whisper of lemon and banana. Finishes briny with mineral qualities.


Palate: much like the nose, bright from start to finish. Bready in the middle with dry crusts while the dough creeps into the finish for a bit of tastebud deceiving fullness. Salt in the finish each and every time. Lemon peel along the edges, a touch dry and waxy. Overall hardness to the flavors which hint at minerals.


Final Thoughts: meh. There used to be a time where I enjoyed Sapporo and if I had to I’d probably drink it again. Maybe. Or not. Too bad some of their more flavorful brews don’t make it to the states. Overall average and that’s not saying much.

At a friend’s party. Pours extremely pale with a white head. Aroma is very weak. Taste is extremely thin. In general, I don’t have a problem with Japanese macro-lagers, but maybe I had my hopes too high for this. Somehow this beer wasn’t watery but was thin never the less. Of course it was perfectly drinkable with no offensive notes to speak of, but it really did not have much in the way of taste either.

bottle: clear golden pour. Tastes like it has a bit of age. grainy, rice and adjunct notes, caramel, a little charred. smooth, sugary some fruity notes and a hint of hop spice. Not bad, would have been better fresh.

Limited on time and cold choices I gave this beer a go. By no means those this beer past for a good beer, but is an upgrade to most of the commercial lagers or pilsners. First taste was surprisingly more complicated than I would have guessed bit finished with s light blandness
Pours a pale straw yellow, nose is grainy and seaweedy, taste is prickly and grainy.
Sample from bottle at the Treasure Coast Beer Fest 9/11/10 Ft Pierce, FL. Nothing special.

Poured from a 22 ounce can. 

The beer pours a yellow color with a white head. The aroma is grain, oranges, lemons and some metal. The majority of the aroma is taken up by the grain, but the citrus hides in the back and occasionally makes an appearance. The flavor is a mix of grassy hops, bready malt and grain. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nothing exciting about the beer, but it is not bad.

Pour from one of those nice 22 oz steel cans. Light amber or darker gold brew, with one finger of white head. Active carbonation aids in head retention. Aroma of light malt with a hint of slightly grassy hops. Flavor is nice but not distinctive - pleasant light malty graininess and a slightly dry finish with a hint of bitter. Nothing bad or unflavorful here at all though, and there is a malty aspect that is nice.
Clear gold, disappearing white head.  Slight herbal aroma.  Flavour is light malts with a sour note and feint hops.
Terrible beer!! Tasted like stale corn and wheat. Ive trie jail house hooch that tasted better than this. Unless thats your thing I dont ever reccomend you waste your money on this beer.

Medium gold, decent sized head.  Aromas of light malt, touch of hops. Flavor is slightly sweet, pretty well-balanced; a bit of bitterness on the finish.  Though it’s nothing very interesting, you can tell this is an all barley malt beer.  Bit more malt quality than normal Sapporo.
Pours clear golden with thick creamy white head and foamy lacing.  Notes of grain and hops.  Slight metallic off-taste, but overall balanced.  Crisp and refreshing.
can thanks to thirdeye11.  poured yellow with a white head.  nose was corn and grains.  not much on the palate, was like any other pale lager.
(650ml can thanks to thirdeye11) Corny smell. Pours a clear yellow. Could use more carbonation. Some malt but not a lot.
(650ml can, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of metal, corn, huskiness, and candy corn.  Flavor of metal, stale crackers, and corn.
(650ml can) medium yellow with a lasting creamy bubbled head. Nose of sugar, raisin, clean grains. Taste of earth, clean grains, corn, well carbonated finish. Decent flavor.

The aroma is really bland and dry with malt and grassy hops. The appearance is right for the style. The taste is like the aroma and too clean. The palate is typical for the style. Overall a very clean beer that is devoid of good flavor.
I don’t think there’s a difference between this and the regular stuff.  Goes well with a Japanese meal, otherwise, isn’t very good.
Not too much difference from the origional sapporo. Pours yellow but not too watery colored, smell is of grass and wheat. Good taste but nothing amazing.
Clear golden pour from the can with a tiny white head that fades fast. Scent is malt, cereal. Taste is typical lager, malty, bready, fizzy feel.

Pours a typical clear golden yellow with a decent white head. Aroma is quite strong and malty, not complex but still inviting. Flavor is strong and malty, enjoyable if not complex. This is a good accompaniment to a meal rather than a "stand alone" beer. Texture is quite tingly and fizzy.

Pours from the 22oz "keg can" straw colored, slightly-darker-than-you-usual-macro yellow with a massive, almost belgian-like head that diminishes by about half and remains at that point.  There’s a veritable storm of bubbles rising & swirling in the glass...almost TOO much carbonation.  Aroma is of sweet malt with an equal dose of funky, metallic grain/overripe fruit.  !st sip is of sweet, cheap malt and a slight pinch of low quality hops. Mouthfeel is thin & watery.  I suppose you could pound a few of these back to back, but it’s so bland and boring, why would you want to?  Overall, not exactly terrible beer, but I see no need for me to ever let this pass my lips again.

Poured from can. Aroma of cereal, slight caramel, some citrus. Pours a clear yellow with a long-lasting, foamy head with some lace. Taste is mostly clean with cereal, yeast, some hops bitterness; however, there’s a faint metallic undertone that I’ve only detected some of the time I’ve had this beer. This used to be my favorite beer, which tells me how far I’ve come -- but it’s still quite sessionable on a hot night.

Pours clear yellow gold with a huge foamy white head that fades pretty quickly. Aroma of apple, corn, rice, and husky grain. Taste is mildly sweet with a slight bitter finish. Very mild, watery, bland, but good cold when thirsty.
Pours light golden brown with a big white head.  Aroma is light breaded malts.  Flavor is light bready malts, with a little bit of metal.  OK.
Slightly cloudy golden yellow color. Clean malt taste with a slight bitter citrus aftertaste. Weak cereal malt aroma.  Overall not that exciting... unless paired with tasty Japanese food.
Not so good. For a big brewer I guess it’s OK. Better than the big 3 but not much. Pours yellow with a fizzy head that goes away. Aroma of any lager. Taste is bland a thin.

Can from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a clear gold with white fizzy head. Aroma of faint malt, faint caramel and very light hop notes. Flavor of light malt, faint toast, light tang, very light hop flavor and bitter. Mouth feel is light body with very high carbonation. Overall, not all that bad, easy to drink.
Big ol’ can from The Whole Foods.  Musty old beer aroma.  Musty old beer taste.

Birthday present from Fratto. Thanks.... Clear golden pour that had a ridiculous head in Fratto’s mug and zero head in my glass. Smells of light grain and honey malts. Some sweetness. Taste has an old quality to it. Not aged mind you, old. Each consecutive sip takes me one step closer to the edge, and I’m about to break. I wonder how old this can was because it tastes like dying grains. I burped and it tasted like asparagus. Uh oh.
Bottle at Oga’s. Pours a dark golden color with a big foamy white head. Nose is grassy, corny and straw. Palate is thin and fizzy. Flavor is grassy and hay some corn notes.

Pale clear golden color.  Aroma is mainly of malts and a little citrus.  Flavor is Pretty much the same with a skunked taste.  Aftertaste is full of dry malts and skunk.  I like the regular one much better than this "reserve".

Oh my great good god....an all malt no dried fish eyball beer from Japan.  I thought to myself as I decided to live dangerously....maybe these guys have actually made a beer that is passable.   This is proof that just hoping for a tradition to change just aint enough.  whoopee its an all malt no rice beer... It still sucks. Nose is of aseptic thin  thin malt.  Body is shamefully weak.  No hops.  Finish is sweet but still on its knees. What was I doing?

22oz super strong can.  Pours a deep gold with a nice fluffy white head.  Aroma is metallic with light malt and slightly grassy hops.  Taste is malty with a slight hoppiness present and a little on the sweet side.  Slightly better than Sapporo Premium.
Pours a golden yellow color with a white head.  Aroma is lemony, floral, honey, and some vanilla.  Flavor is malty, floral, lemon, and a bitter lemony finish.

16oz: drinking glass: fairly decent brew... had this immediately after the original.  Although the body is still very thin, there is more hops and grains... still medium to high carbonation that washes the palate clean.  Easily drinkable with sushi.
&#40bottle&#41. Clear gold color. Medium white head. Light grainy aroma and flavor. Short duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.
Yellow pour with a big frothy head. Aroma of  grain, basic malt, very light and unimpressive. Flavor is unimpressive, just like most lagers, with maybe a bit more flavor. Decidedly mediocre.
Drank straight from the big can while visiting Hawaii... maybe poured it into a hotel glass.  Typical lager and nothing special about it.

Slightly hazy golden color. Looked better in the can, which is quite an attractive aluminum can, so I poured it back into the can (after you read the rest of the review you’ll see why). 

Smell is very grain-alcohol-y, chemical, and fairly tame. Very similar to most domestic macros. 

Taste is very light in all aspects, again with a macro character on the whole, and that annoying chemical taste. What is that taste? I can’t find the right word. 

Finish is short and dry. 

The nice thing about this beer is the fancy can. Unlike regular Sapporo this can has nice barley designs on both sides of the can. very attractive. This beer is far more enjoyable straight from the can - if you must drink one at all.

11/09/2007:  Sapporo Reserve is crisp and clean with a pale maltiness that is balanced by a mild grassy bitterness.  The aroma is a bit grainy.  The beer is medium-light and has a transparent golden color, moderate carbonation, and a foamy and somewhat diminishing off-white head.  This beer is refreshing and not too bad.  It is better than expected and would probably go well with spicy food since it would help to cleanse the palate.



16 fl. oz. can from The Party Source in Bellevue, Kentucky.  Rating #217 for this beer.
Can. Much better if the two sapporo beers tryed next to each other. Still a very light flavored beer. Not awful.

This was acually a pleasant surprise. Didn’t get a good look at it, since I drank it from the can, but the aroma was pretty non descript and macro like. Kind of sweet, little floral hop, kind of dusty smelling. The taste was floral, with peat and a hint of sweet malt. Maybe I’m crazy but it faintly reminded me of a single malt scotch. Faintly. Overall, not bad. I may revisit this one later.

Magnum Can: Golden color with a light fizz. The nose is mild with some malt and a little thin hops. Grassy would be a stretch. Crisp flavor and a decent body for sapporo. Better than their usual but I don’t know if reserve would be an appropriate descriptor.

Can.  Pours light gold/yellow with a 3 finger stark white head that leaves spotty lacing.  The nose is grassy hops and malt.  The taste is sweet malt, grain, grassy and metallic hops.  Lighter mouthfeel.  Meh, not great but refreshing.

Med. Gold with thick white pillowy head.
Aroma is not bad, light malt sweetness, not too grainy, very light grassy hop.
Flanour is sweet malt, grassy hop again. Not bad.
Pours deep golden color with a white head. Very sweet malty aroma. Light flavor, sweet malt and bread. Was good for washing down spicy sushi but probably not much else.
22 oz can pours brilliant golden with a decent white head and a sweet malty aroma. Flavor is light hop bitterness and sweet malt. Light and easy to drink. I think I like the regular version better.

medium golden yellow, big head, lots of lacing.  nice maulty aroma.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is of light-medium roasted malts - lots of malts.  light hoppy finish that is overall pretty smooth.notes of toasted wheat bread, corn and dough.
Overall a nice light bodied beer - I would have no problem having this again.
Ick. This smells, like...ick... It looks shitty. Too thin, on all accounts. It leaves a bad taste in my mouth, but it’s not terrible.

With great shame, I purchased and drank this beer in honor of the Super Bowl, where cheap lagers runneth over in the chalices of avid sports fans.  Without a TV and without interest, I drink this to honor my manliness and American-ness while writing a paper.  What’s there to say?  The can is a great design, but it tastes corny and thin.  In fact, it doesn’t taste bad.  It just tastes like water.  Too bad I didn’t just have a glass of water.  Maybe this is better when watching Japanese baseball games.

This beer has a rice type quality that gives is a slight sharpness from the original Sapporo.  The beer also has a malt liquor bite which will hit you if your not careful.  It is drinkable and flavorful  and definetly goes well with Asian food.  Overall, a good brew, but I wish it had a better appearance.  It is slightly cloudy whihc really takes away a lot of the top quality of the beer to me.
Nice clear gold with fair white head, mild bitterness from beginning to end, a bit watery, wouldn’t recommend...but the can looks great.

A- Pours a clear golden straw hue with small white head that is mostly diminishing, very little in terms of lacing
S- Fairly clean and simple nose of non-descript grain malts and a touch of hop sweetness
T- Refreshing and clean taste dominate by very slightly sweetened malts, some floral and herbal tones in the background as well as earthy flavors, finish is dry and quickly dissipates
M- Light-bodied, watery texture, adequate carbonation
D- If I could give this beer extra credit, it would be for drinkability, this is clean and refreshing with a nice full, simple malt flavor, I would place this at the top of my session beer list and think this is a great choice for a summer beach beer

Pours VERY high soapy head with large bubbles. Nicely clear. Light yellow body. Not nearly as much carbonation as I’d expect from a beer of this type. Not the greatest of aromas. Not distracting unless you purposely try and catch a whiff for a beer rating! Flavor swings to the malt side of the spectrum, but not overly malty. Hops? I guess they’re in there. Clean palate. I bought a couple of bottles to wash the guacamole down while watching the Super Bowl, and happened to have one left for this rating. Will buy again when I’m looking for something inexpensive and clean in flavor.
22 oz. purchased at Central Market in Mill Creek, WA.  Pours a light golden color:  Flavor: Somewhat sweet, some corn, with little hops.

Super can, with sushi take out. Actually, mega can is more appropriate. Even when the beer is poured this thing is still got some weight to it! Anyway, I don’t see the "reserve" status here. Apple-fruit accented grainy aroma. Lagery, papery, clean. It does the job as a palate cleanser with the sushi but there really isn’t much to go on about.
Golden pour with a fizzy head.  Pretty standard macro lager, with the addition of a hint of citrus.  I did not get any skunkiness, which may be because I poured from a can.  Just a beer.

22oz. can pours clear golden with thick white head that quickly disapates. Aroma is a little bit of malt. First taste is watery malt and not much else. Carbonation is high, flavor is low. I often drink regular sapporo because it is cheap but this was not worth the extra $$.
Tasting at Brewtopia.  Reserve?? What??? Piss poor.  Yellow beer.  White head.  Aromas of corn, malt, slight hops.  Nasty flavor.  I don’t get it.  PREMIUM?  HELL NO.

This was definitely the best of a recent tour of Asian beers I took (all without leaving Wisconsin), but that is still not saying all that much.  This beer pours a darker color than regular Sapporo, which is something that you might expect from a beer called "reserve."  This beer offers some up nice maltiness, which came to me as a baking bread aroma and flavor.  More than I expected, but hardly terric.
Dark golden color with carbonation.  Tall white head.  Nil aroma-some hops and bread.  Not much of a beer.

9/20/08 From 660ml can, Cans, Tacoma, Wa. Aroma is strangely a blend on noble hop flora and fresh baked whole grain bread. Appearance is clear gold with a low white head. Flavor is sour pils malt forward with a strong noble hop background and medium bittering. Mouthfeel is very low bodied with a medium/high carb texture. Overall, not very easy drinking, but more character than expected.

bottle picked up by girlfriend.  poured a clear gold with a whit head.  aroma of malt, lemon, and some skunkiness.  flavor of malt and feint lemon.  light body and high carb.  i had higher expectations for this one.

22oz can poured into glass. Yellowish gold with a foamy white head.  Malty aroma and not much else.  Start of cereal malt taste that ends abruptly for not much of a finish.  Overall nothing that stands out but an average beer to sip on.

22oz can.   Light gold with a sturdy white head.   Herb, leaf, metal, and soap aroma.   Slightly honeyish, crackery malts with an abrasively bitter herbal finish that really isn’t too bitter.   Light body with lively carbonation.   Not terrible, but the bitterness in the finish is not jelling with the watery malt profile.

Can.  Super Premium?  not so much.  Pours a straw yellow in color with a big white head.  The aroma is malty, but not of filler corn/rice.  It is a pretty clean, non-descript lager.  The can, however is still almost indestructable, which is kind of cool.

A predictably dull beer that surpasses American lager standards but is still completely forgettable. Drinkable, and nothing more. I should add that the can is made of a kevlar-titanium alloy;  Virtually indestructible, crush-proof and ICBM-proof.
bottle, golden yellow pour, nice white head, nose is fruity, flavor is malt with mango and apple, medium malt finish

Awesome big shiny can bought at the Utah State Store. Pours a clear golden body with a medium foamy head. A pleasant aroma of sweet malt, grasses and light floral hops. The taste is very smooth and quaffable; a smooth rich malt presence, it leaves your palate cleanly and ends with a pure watery feel. Just a touch of hops too. Not bad at all, good quality always comes through.

Pint bottle. Pours clear dark gold with a lacy white head. Unfortunate catty edge to the nose. Hard to get around it, but behind the cat is a bit of fruit, grass and spice. Medium body and minimal carbonation. Lightly sweet taste with honey, bread and grass. The finish sort of wanders off into the weeds. I was hoping for a bit more from a super-duper premium lager with "only finest European barley, and the most select European hops. "

Bottle. 22 oz. Poured a light clear gold. Not a whole lot going on in the nose. Tasted pretty similar to a miller lite actually. So, better than I expected for a Jap beer. But still not a good brew as Miller Lite is only good for chugging. Cool can though.

Bottle from John’s Market Place in PDX--Poured a bubbly straw yellow-golden body with a wimpy white head.  Aroma is a blend of malts, rice, and mild spicy hops.  Not too skunky, but a little nonetheless.  Sharp carbonic mouthfeel that finishes quite bitterly and super dry.  Nice Canadian beer--Ha!
clear gold with a large foamy white head.  sweet malt aroma.  flavor is moderately sweet with a hint of stale hops.  low carbonation.  smooth.  reminds me of apple juice.

Nice looking can: The color of the can and beer match perfectly.  Aroma is a mild mix of malt and hops.  Flavor is crisp, but sharp astringency with a touch of a metallic bite, not much though.  Palate is dry and with a tinge of hops.  I don’t like getting buzzed with little or no flavor...

I thought I would follow Garrett Olivers advise and try some light lagers while I grill up some seafood. Pours gold with a tall white head. I’m not sure I remember having Sapporo before, but this wasn’t all that bad, crisp, soft hops, non-skunked from being in the can. Not all that bad, although I have to say that is a pretty heavy can.
Very light yeast aroma. Clear golden color with a small white head. Tangy and sweet flavor in the beginning that gradually grow stronger to the finish.
Pours a golden pale body with a white head.  Pale with a poor malt and a skunky bitter rice flavor.  Pass on this one.

Pours with a largish, foamy, off-white head covering a deep yellow body. Aroma is a bit of wheat and maybe a little corn, with a fruity note at the end. Ultra thin mouthfeel. A  little bit spicy and metallicy. There is also an odd apple taste to the beer. Interesting Japanese lager.

Beer. Nothing more nor less. Did pour with a big foamy frothy head and a bit of lace. Golden amber color. Nose was beery. Oddly mouthfilling but still watery. Hops are there but there’s a play between the bitterness and neutral sweetness. Beer burps. Serviceable. Almost a session beer if you don’t want anything too bold. Got this one at the big local supermarket.
Yellowish color with some white head.  Taste has a touch of maltiness with some hops to balance it.  Aromas of malts, hops.  Typical lager nothing great.
Yellow in color with a mediocre white head. Aromas of grain, corn and grass. Flavors of the same with a slight hoppiness. A little weak all around.

Can. Pours hazy yellow, white head. Aroma is malt, ketchup. Flavor is the same. This is pretty bad. Worse than regular Sapporo. Also, this was brewed in Canadialand. The Sapporo actually brewed in Japan tastes better.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden color with enough head. It’s clean, yet cloudy, a marvel. Obviously from Japan’s oldest brewery since the claimed all malt beverage has hops in it too. Smells like crisp malt and light hops. Surprisingly good. Is this a lager? Ususally lagers suck because they take so much time, effort, and marketing sell, I mean produce. A pleasant revival for the lager style of beer. AB and SABMiller need pay attention.

doughy is the first, strongest flavor.  Some honey, apple, pear.  A bit of a crispness, but a little thick in the palate, fighting off that crispness.  Light crisp hop spice, cold do with more.  Pretty good for what it is.
relatively crisp clean easy to drink beer. one of the better sapporo’s I have had. a little over priced though

22 oz. bottle poured into lager glass- poured transparent thin golden yellow, white head formed and stayed for a few minutes but eventually went away, medium carbonation of small bubbles, aroma of light hops, grass, and weak wheat.  HIts the mouth with a thin body, the malt is very light but easily detectable, a few hops on the finish.  Ok brew, drinkable and balanced.
22 oz can at a Vietnamese restaurant in Philly. The beer pours a clear yellow with some carbonation and white head. Nothing at all is offensive about this beer. Easy to drink as well.

Light copper-golden color with a fluffy white head. This was poured from a sturdy 22 ounce aluminum can. Surprised to find this is brewed in Canada. Nice sweet maltiness with slighty bitter hops.. A nice beer that is at least one step up from American macros. I enjoyed it quite a bit for a lighter (taste-wise) beer. Nice dry finish. Recommended.

Meh. Better than the Yebisu Mellow Premium but just the same nothing special. Solid lager though. Sapporo got some skills. 16oz bottle from Don Quijote(Honolulu) formerly Daiei. NOTE: I actually had this beer a long time ago in the more typical can as pictured here in the profile. When I picked this up I was not aware it was the same thing as the new bottled version uses completely different labeling.

Can.  Pours a clear, amber colour...darker than expected.  Light carbonation and no real head.  Aroma is all sweet malt, maybe hints of caramel and hop.  Mostly hop flavour but finishes with a strange, flat bitterness.

this beer pours a golden yellow with a thin tan head.  Not a whole to say about this, the aroma is skunky and bland.  the flavors pretty much agree with this.  This was not a good ber, but I did find it easy to drink...  Won’t get this one again.  Cheers

Pale golden, thick white head.  Fine carbonation.  The aroma is lightly herbal with a nice noble and floral hop aroma.  Light biscuity malts and a soft creamy palate.  Minerally bitterness.  The beer is actually quite balanced and tasty.  One of the better things to come out of Guelph in quite some time.

Can, shared by my roommate.  Nice yellow-gold clear pour with some foamy white head.  Aroma of slightly sweet corn malt and some eastern european hops.  Flavor is the same, slightly medicinal / herbal tasting.  Would have been even better on a hot summer day.

650ml Can - The Liquor Collection - Honolulu, Hawaii 

2008 – Great Hawaiian Beer Run

Aroma – A light ale aroma this was weak from the start to finish with aroma. 

Appearance – Light golden color, clear with a nice head. 

Flavor – A decent lager flavor.  This beer went down fast and cold and it was good for the buzz I needed that night.   
 
Palate – Good Mouthfeel, with a dry finish. 

Overall – Not my favorite style this was a beer that I tried for fun it was decent and for a hot day not bad to drink.

Beautiful clear deep golden body with a huge white head ...  looks like a perfect lager.  Nose is off putting ... not strong, but slightly stinky, slightly grassy.  Aluminum is opaque; how do you skunk canned beer?  Taste is disappointing:  nicely bitter, not enough malt for balance, metallic aftertaste.  Thin in the mouth, even for a lager.  Not bad as a macro lager, might even work with sushi and vinegar rice.  I’m going to use this can as cooking beer, not as football-watching beer.
Pours a gold color with a moderatley sized white head. Very yeasty aroma. Full of malt flavor, but also a little bitterness. Not much body to it. Better than most American macros.

650ml can from Vons. Pours a translucent brass color with a small white head that fades to nothing in 3 min and leaves some lacing in the glass. The Aroma is light with dusty biscuits and some yeast. The flavor was malty, but undistinguished, and had notes of something metallic. The mouthfeel was thin and watery up front but finished somewhat sticky. The finish was short, sweet and yeasty. Overall: This is better than US macro BMC selections, reminds me a bit of Fosters Lager; but--Not Recommended.

10-13-07 can. 

Watery golden color with short-lived head.  Filthy yeasty malt aroma.  Overly crabonated.  Watery bland taste.  Just not very good.

Aggressive pour yields a straw gold color with decent head that quickly dissappears.  Sweet honey malt aroma with corn or rice tinge.  Taste is similar with small amount of herbal tasting hops.  Malt dominates.  Thin body.  Finish is somewhat astringent.  Better than most macros.

What can I say, I was curious to try it b/c of the can...  Light golden clear pour with a decent head.  Smell was surprisingly skunky, lager malt/yeast smell, and watery with a good amount of metal aroma and flavor.  Just watery, boring, and not particularly good at all overall.  Kind of a watery golden/blonde ale flavor about it...

16oz bottle - Pours bright yellow with a mostly receding white head. Aroma of macro lager yeast, slightly metallic, and bitter hops. Taste is lightly bitter, metallic, and slightly corny. Mouthfeel is light bodied, slightly bitter with moderate carbonation. Why did I get my hopes up! This still tastes like adjunct brew...
First time I tried this, pretty good. 22oz can poured into a glass. Nice golden color, white foamy head, good flavor.

Can (22-oz). A pretty nice/distinctive can actually. Aroma is light bready malt, maybe a hint of European-style hops. Flavor has a fairly good malt backbone, with again a hint of hops, and moderate acidity. A reasonable lager, and to my surprise actually better than the normal Sapporo lager.
A strong dark Lager. Pretty good. malty aroma. Pours gold dark yellow head. Originally I picked it up because I thought the can looked cool.
Sweet and malty in the aroma. Pours gold.  A pretty nice gold color actually. Light malt flavor,a little bread, with a super crisp finish. Very basic but it gets the job done.

Date: 08/09/2001

Mode: Can

Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta



dark yellow, frothy head, slight skunk aroma (from a can?), light malt flavor, touch of bitterness, not bad



Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 3/10; Overall: 7/20

Rating: 1.8/5.0
Score: *+/4

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Poured slightly darker than your average pale lager with a foamy white, two-finger head.  Some lacing.  The aroma was malty, slightly herbal and even a bit of citrus.  The flavor was almost pure malt.  Some hints of hop bail this thing out at the end.  The mouthfeel is thin and almost overcarbonated.
Can, off gold Tastes just like regular sapporo would taste, but way maltier.  not bad.

sun gold with yellow white dissolving head leaving nice lace medium thick creamy body with light carbonation. grain and slight vanilla earth aroma, grainy malt with some light cream and carmel good refreshing restaurant beer

Aroma of light grass and noticeable malt. Orange tinged gold coor with a white head that collapsed, but left some lacing. Medium+ mouthfeel; low carbonation; sort of a warm malt foundation, and there is definitely some decent pilsener type hop in the finish. If it was not quite so malty, and had a bit more hop, I’d think it actually was a pilsener. Way better than Bud.

not bad. has some good components, but something is lacking. enjoyed at mt. fuji with a spicy menu. dry and low on flavor. grainy and interestingly strongish carbonation. smooth,grassy,ricey and moderate of body.
Can...Pours well...clear amber color...decent head...Great with sushi but wouldn’t drink with any other dishes.
A bit richer than it’s premium draft version. This beer has more malt and more body. Overall it is very similar to the regular Sapporo. Good with sushi... When else would you drink it?

Body is a nice gold hue, thick fluffly white head.  Aroma is lightly maltly, with corn, very light hops in the background.  Taste is decent, easy drinking, not overcarbonated, taste has a light hop content, light caramel note, with the malts playing through.  Pretty good for a ’premium lager.’

Been a long time since I’ve had something from a can...Having said that, it was better than I expected.  Not great, but not bad for a can.  Pours gold with a tall fizzy head.  Goes down relatively smooth, but has a bit of skunkiness.
Aroma is grainy and light malt.  Appearance is clear gold with a fizzy head.  Flavor is light and pissy.  Tastes of grain, some malt, and a little sweetness.

This brew is not so bad, nothing special just your average malt liquor on a saturday night a touch of light continental hops, with very light  malts fortunately no rice sweetness. Not bad but noot great.

Can 22 oz.
Pours clear, gold with a medium white head. Smooth tasting and easy drinking. Not bad for a macro brew.

Can 22oz. Clear light amber with large white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sweet aroma. Light to medium body. Light sweet flavor with light sweet finish of short duration. Soft drinkable beer.

Bottle, head-to-head against Sapporo Premium Draft (also bottled).

Pours a deeper gold than the premium draft, and offers a richer, malter aroma, albeit with much of the same sour, grassy, slightly skunky tones that I get from the Premium Draft. The flavor certainly is richer in the malts; here I actually get a nice mouth full of cookie-dough malt and some fairly apparent grassy hops on the finish. By comparison, the Premium Draft is weak and watery.

It’s not outstanding in any way, nor it is even very good - but it is a couple of notches better than the more common Sapporo Premium Draft,  and as such makes it a decent choice over the other Japanese macro lagers.
reserve?!?! Its not bad, but hell its pretty fall from great, its OK...Yellow color, some fizzy white hed, some lacing, FAINT honey smell, sits nicely on the tongue but falls short.. refreshing!

22 oz Can. Aroma starts out like an aluminum can. By finish smells like a urine sample. Appearance is murky yellow also with a good white head. Doesn’t have that over bitter wet corn malt to it. A rather smooth beer to drink wondering what all those drunk Demacrats will do next. A calming influence I guess.

22 oz. can.  Yellow-gold with a lot of bubbles.  Basic pale lager straw/dead grass aroma.   Doughy malt flavor but with an unpleasant saltiness leaving a bad aftertaste, which could be from poor storage, but who knows?  At best, another Canadian brewed macrolager disguised as a chic special offering from the edge of the globe, packaged in a designer can.

22 oz aluminum can:  Poured into a Pint Glass.  Aroma is a lightly hopped, somewhat of a malt backing, rice, with some very light citrus aroma.  Appearance is a pale straw color with a fluffy white head.  There is an good medium bodied maltiness to the taste which I am pleasantly surprised.  With a light bitterness and some actual hop characteristics throughout, and a light citrus taste on the back end.  Palate is bitter, long, quite carbonated, and rather lively.  Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by this brew.  I had some actual malt and hops characteristics in it and wasn’t just yellow rice water like regular Sapporo, and other American marco’s.  Nice!

From a 22 oz. shaped can, for a can, really nice presentation, with a freshness date on the bottom of the can.

Poured a chill hazy good lager golden with a foamy, fluffy white head, good retention, a small amount of laced, ringed sticking.

Aromas of a sweet grain metallic, a subtle lemon tea and floral.

Good, smooth carbonation and a malty crisp, creamy medium bodied mouthfeel.

A nice, smooth all malt lager taste, floral and lemon tea hops at first, good and soft in their bitterness, sweet grainy with a fine metallic edge, a tea fruitiness towards the end and a dryish grainy finish.

This is my personal favorite from the beers by Sapporo I’ve tried, goes great with all kinds of food, especially seafood and sushi.

The 22 ounce can poured a sparkling clear light golden copper colored beverage with a modest, fizzy white head that was mostly diminishing but left very little lacing on the glass. The aroma was well balanced with a good malty presence. It also had a subtle floral hop character in the background. The body was medium-light with lively carbonation and a crisp, thirst quenching texture. The flavor started off slightly bitter with good malt underpinnings. The finish was medium in length and the light bitterness and malt characters held true to the end.

Clear copper with a lot of carbonation. The head left without much to say. Toasted malts. Some caramel and some fruits in the hops. A touch of a buttery aroma. The caramel is stronger with a lot more of the toasted malts. Some bitterness there at the end. Thick and malty body. Husky finish.

had the reserve the classic and the regular?  this one may have had a bit more of a cereal malt flavor to it then the others.  it states its brewed twice as long as other? what the hell does that mean to this one dimensional beer more starches from the rice?
Bottle. Is this a beer? I have no idea want I am doing drinking this things. Trying to get to a 1000 may not be worth it. Very little aroma beer or otherwise. Taste? What taste?

Thanks to Lisa Wolters for this...
Appears a solid, crisp gold with a 2 finger white head that slowly fades out. Medium amounts of carbonation rise to the top. Some sticky streaks of lacing is left around the interior of the glass.
Smell is of doughy, grainy, dried corn, and a metallic, earthy, floral note infused with honey.
Taste is of the same aromas. Nothing special in there though. Pretty run of the mill Euro lager.
Mouthfeel is metallic, honey sweet, and mildly bitter. This is medium bodied and crisp.
Pale lager, but much less malty and more bitter than the regular Sapporo.  Very pleasant, with a refreshing carbonation.

16oz bottle, brewed in Canada. Pours crystal-clear golden, with a moderate white head. Malty, little to no hop. Not many flavours jump out. It’s an unimpressive lager. Better than the macros, but not by much. I don’t know if it’s just my mind associating the two Asian brews, but it does bear a resemblance to Tsingtao.

22 oz can.  Golden clear with a decent head that actually stuck around for a while.  Aromas were a little weak and were a bit  sour.  I guess it was good that they were weak.  flavors were better.  Malt with some hops.  A little soapy on the finish, but drinkable.

This bottled brew from the Mikado Restaurant in Indianapolis poured a small sized head of foamy white colored bubbles that left behind a transparent carbonated orange colored body and a fair lacing.  The aroma was mild and malt liquorish with a mild bready doughy note.  The mouth feel was mild smooth and creamy.  It also had a good smooth thick malt flavor that was rather tasty.
Gold with a small white head. Grainy, sweet corn aroma; Malty lager flavor, but you can taste more hops than typical American macros, a little bitterness in the finish.
Can. pours deep golden with a decent sized white head. Aroma of grain, sweet malts, citrus. Flavor is sweet, citrus, grainy, corn. Decent body,decent brew.

Not as horrible as I thought it would be.  I had the "premium," which was horrible, and I found this to have a little more character and be a bit better, though they are pretty similar beers overall.  Jabberwoky japanesey.
Big ass silver can.  Sweet corn and honey aroma, somewhat of a starchy, rough palate with flavors of corn husk and raw grains (straw?).  Finish is mildly peppy, yeasty.  Not bad, not exciting though.

Can served at Genji’s in Midland, MI. Pours golden amber with a medium creamy off-white head with pretty good lacing. Aroma of corn and malt. Body is typical for a "premium" lager, not too light but not rich either. Unassertive malt and hops flavors don’t really register, but at the same time it is flavorful enough to not be bland. The finish is mildly hoppy. Drinkable, especially with spicy Japanese food but I wouldn’t bother with this otherwise.

Mmm. I’ve had Sapporo Reserve many times during my first year in university. Four or five cans of this will complete your night! Oh right, the taste. Sapporo Reserve had a grassy taste, with a clean, refreshing, astringent finish. Adequate carbonation. It wasn’t that watery though. No skunky scent. A shame that I did not complement this with Japanese food, as I chugged this down numerous times!

Pours deep golden with a quickly fading white head. Apple and caramel in the nose. Flavor has notes of grain, caramel, toasty malt and pear. Pretty full-bodied; moderate sweetness and bitterness. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Drinkable, but nothing special.

Pours a slighty hazy yellow gold with very little white head.  Not much aroma or flavor.  Thin body with a clean hop finish.  I guess this is a little better than your average large bewery lagers, but nothing amazing here.

Bottle at Mikado in downtown Indianapolis, IN. Small off-white fizzy head that mostly diminished, fair lacing, transparent, carbonated, and a yellow hue. Malty and some hops in the nose. Flavor was malty and somewhat bitter. Smooth palate. Light body.

(22 oz can: $2.49 at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) Date stamped on bottom of can: L1105, which I presume is 11-Dec-05.  Expecting another bad imported pale lager, Sapporo Reserve in the fancy can is actually not bad at all.  It’s clean, somewhat crisp, quite grassy, lightly sweet, and grainy, but mostly, it just has a nice, pleasant, drinkable flavor that I wish all pale and premium lagers had.  I’m really appreciating drinking a beer of this style that shows obvious hops and malt rather than adjuncts and unpleasant bitterness.  Grassy, grainy, malty nose isn’t remarkable, but certainly pleasant enough.  Light-medium body is more than sufficient for the style, and with moderate carbonation and light crispness, this is clean and refreshing on the palate.  Medium straw in color with excellent clarity, I would like a few more carbonation bubbles rising through the beer to maximize the beauty of a beer like this.  The very bubbly, snow-white head doesn’t quite reach a full inch in height and settles by the bubbles merging together into larger bubbles, but eventually settles to a normal ring.  Compared side-by-side with Kirin Ichiban, the Sapporo Reserve is better tasting and more flavorful by leaps and bounds.  For the style, it just doesn’t get a whole lot better than this beer.

(can - 650 ml) Slightly hazy gold color with about a half inch of fizzy white head that quickly fizzes out. Light aroma of malts with a touch of grain and possibly some hops. The taste begins with a sweet and malty flavor followed by a bitter and metallic middle and watery and bitter finish. Aftertaste is gently bitter.
Can: Light amber colour, with a medium heavy white head lots of carbonation. Aroma with hops. Taste is quite decent for a lager, crisp, hoppy with a good balance of bitterness and sweetness.

12 oz bottle.  There is really not much difference between Sapporo, Kirin, and Asahi.  All 3 are Coor’s light type clones.  I mean come on, do you expect rally good beer from Japan?  No, of course not.  You expect good food!

Sapporo Reserve is a very well done beer. The label states that this beer is brewed with "the finest barley and European hops". That is not surprising, German brewers were sent to Japan in the latter half of the 19th Century to teach the Japanese how to brew beer. This Germanic influence can be seen today in Japanese beer styles, most notably in "black beer", a German style of dark lager that has survived in Japan, and is still being brewed there to this day.(see my review of Sapporo Stout for details.) Sapporo Reserve is not a schwarzbier, but is more along the lines of a malty German helles, bordering on maibock. 

Sapporo Reserve pours to a beautiful, bright, golden color with a nice white head, and a lively carbonation. The nose on this beer is very enjoyable. Really nice aromas of malt marry with some grassy hop aromatics. The palate is firm, good pale malt flavors are round and clean on the tongue. This beer finishes with more good malt character and is balanced with some good, dry hop bitterness. This is a very balanced beer. The label states "malt liquor", which translates that its abv is higher, I’m guessing around 6-7% avb. 

I enjoyed this beer very much, it reminded me of a good malty helles style beer poured at Oktoberfest in Germany, or even a Maibock. The emphasis on the label was European hops, but the malt character of this beer impressed me the most. Hops are there, but only to balance. I would match this beer with Japanse fare such as sushi, or perhaps grilled fish or chicken.
This is nothing at all like regular Sapporo. Its more like one fantastic premium lager. It’s really smooth and complex. I was very pleasantly surprised by this.
Bottle - slightly skunky malt aroma.  No noticeable hops.  Looked like Bud Light.  Flavor was much like the aroma, but with a strong corn taste.  Not real good.

Buttery-golden, fairly dead except for a white head that lasts as a 1cm cap. Light aromas of grain and adjunct grains. Flavor is grassy-sour-bitterness with malts coming through late with a touch of sweet. Light- to mid-bodied. Mostly harmless.


Jewel/Osco, Oak Lawn, IL 60453
Light sweet grassy aroma. Pale golden color with a medium white head. Flavor starts lightly sweet and grainy turning fairly bitter (grassy) with a crisp dry finish. Thin texture, lively carbonation.
Gold Coloring with White Skin.  Rice Aroa.  Rice/Corny Flavor. Dry Ending.  Actually Much Easier to Handle Then the Regular Version.

Light amber colour.  Light pale malt, fusel and grassy hop aroma. Mild bitterness from noble varieties, light pale malt sweetness and macroish acidity on the palate.  Why are so many macrobrews tart like this?
Gold color with a thin head.  Aroma of sweet grains.  The taste takes an unfortunate turn for sourville.  Standard macro.

650 ml Can: Pretty much the same as Sapporo Draft. The can is the most exciting part of it. More or less has the same taste as Draft, but slightly more robust due to the all malt (or so they say) brewing. Seems to have more of the aromatic floral scent to it - not sure what that is all about. Tastes like roses to, to a point. Finishes very dry, with no notable aftertaste - Japanese Dry to a T. Definitely recommended over Sapporo Draft, but its hard to find, at least in my area.
This beer was deeper in color and maltier than the standard Sapporo.  I really prefer the regular Sapporo more with Sushi.
i did not like this beer. it did not have a nice flavor that stoud out amoung lagers.

Not quite clear, fat white head and golden in color. Fruity, spicy, ester aroma with a hint of alcohol. Somewhat dirty flavor reminding me of an ashtray. Vegetable finish. I think this bottle is past its prime.

Sampled from can (and a cool one at that). Reserve pours a clear gold with a lsting, creamy white head and thick, intricate lacing. Aroma is mild and unassertive with just notes of malts. Flavor is balanced and clean with a faint floral hop addition. Full bodied for the style and carbonated lightly. A simple, refreshing all-malt lager.
INteresting, and nice too, better than the normal Sapporo beer. I liked but it is very heavy to drink it all. NIce.
Kind of a suprise in color here, more amber than expected.  Weak aroma and little to no head.  Taste is smooth but weak.  Not bad, but nothing special.
Canadian Version. Not much going on here. I do hold the notion that I liked this better when it was Japanese. Very run of the mill.

Can.  Barley and soy sauce aroma.  Golden amber color with small head.  Strong soy sauce flavor - corn/rice grain flavor as well.  This was the first Asian beer I ever tried - attributed the soy sauce flavor to the food but trying it again with no Asian food in sight, it has to be the beer.  Could probably get the same flavor by putting a couple drops of soy sauce in a light beer.
Gold pour, with corny hops and some honey in the taste and finish.  The finish is dry, and the body is a step above the BMC stuff.
Pour is yellow with a white head.  Aroma and flavor are almost non-existant.  Bland as the blandest lager can be.

Can poured yellow with a good white head.
Aroma of spice, corn, malt, grass.
Flavor is corn and grass with a bitter, heavy metalic finish...not too bad...I am watching karate kid two as i’m drinking this and the japanese chick he is with is hot...I want one to drink this beer with.

ah, my second consecutive beer brewed in canada but marketed otherwise.  this was sweet and had a strange finish/aftertaste that was not very welcome.  not the typical premuim import lager.  so it scores a few points for being a bit different, but that doesnt make up for the funky taste
Extra sweet corn syrup taste, with a mixture of alcohol and green vegetables.  The taste wears a thin and fizzy body that is a bit acidic on the tongue.  Not great, but oddly drinkable.
Wow, I need a shower after this. Aroma is like brussel sprouts, and the flavor matches. Thin white head over thin yellow body. Looks and feels overcarbonated.

Bottle.  Apparently contract brewed out of Canada.  The yellow was a bit richer in color than I expected, but the fizzy head died off quickly.  The aroma and flavor are very standard for foreign lagers, though this is a bit drier than I expected (despite the tinge of syrupy palate suggesting sweetness), and a metallic edge to the finish was an additional "down" note.  Pretty unenjoyable, even for what it tries to be.
Can. Over-carbonated pale yellow with a tiny head that vanished almost immediately. Nose: creamed corn and stale cabbage. Flavor: corn bread and vegetable water. Thin body.
Aroma is that of a non offensive lager. In other words, nothing else is there. Typical clear light golden color with a reasonable sized head. For a lager it was fine.

Aroma of corn (though I guess it’s not supposed to have any in the recipe) overlaying the slightest hint of malt; some aluminum.  Appears a light golden color with light effervescence of medium-sized bubbles amd with a white head that dissipates quickly.  Flavor is metallic lemon over skunk.  It finishes slightly sweet with a faint hop bitterness (maybe saaz?).  Palate if overl carbonated and moderately light.  Overall this beer is dissapointing but equal to the sum of its parts.

Poured a golden color color with a medium sized white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Harsh aroma of sweet corn and grains.  Corn and malts in the taste, with a very light bop bitterness.  A nice break between sakes.
Pour is golden yellow fizzy with expected short lived white head...smell is wet dog and grass...taste is general bland skunk...SURPRISE

Light straw gold, big puffy white head.  Nose sweet, some cardboard, bit vegetable-ish.  Pretty basic flavor, generic premium lager, sweet and malty, grassy, some vague hops in the end.  Reasonably decent for what it is.

musty aroma of old wood, dried grass, and wet cardboard.  Transparent yellow color with solid sheet of white froth.  Has a yeasty character to the flavor that makes it somewhat interesting..a bit watery though.  Straw & grass flavors predominate...with a touch of herbal citrus in the background.  I once had a "bad" bottle of this stuff that tasted like a lager version of beatrix..This bottle here though was not quite beatrix quality..however, it still is quite nice for what it is.
