Pours straw fold with a voluminous whit head.  Not much aroma to speak of, a bit of grassiness maybe.  Flavor is actually pretty decent, good balance between malt and hops and no typical macro articificial-ness.  This is a pleasant drink.

Bottle.  Bright golden, eggshell head.  The smell isn’t so "reserved", it’s just grainy and not very pleasant.  Bland malty flavor with hints of wheat.  Normally here’s the part where I tell some elaborate story of how I happened upon my latest crappy Asian lager on my quest for 100, but nope, nothing to see here, I just bought it at Central Market.  Sapporo’s website says "Drink in the world".  I suppose their corporate plans don’t include interplanetary expansion.

Clear yellow, with a decent-sized white head. Light aroma of honey, malt. This tasted surprisingly inoffensive, with honey dominating the profile, and only hints of corn and a slight metallic bite marring the flavor.

From a 22 oz. can. Dark gold with a large white head. Aroma of carrots and celery with some white bread. The taste is A full vegetable with some celery and leaf lettuce. This is fairly inoffensive, I guess.

Pours a medium yellow with a head that quickly dissipates to nothing. Initial grain aromas, nothing offensive. Some hop flavor with a generic malt sweetness in the background. Decent on its own, but it would be alot better with some spicy Asian food. 22oz can perfect tallboy size. Brewed in Canada "IMported" to US.
pours pale, clear yellow with no distinguishable head. aroma is light hops, slightly malty.  flavor is somewhat sweet, some malts, a little hoppy. Nothing special, but not horrible

Pours a respectable golden color with a good-sized white head on top.  Aroma is suprisingly good, fairly hoppy, which I did not expect from such a commercial brew.  Flavor is cheaper malts balanced by hops, which is again pretty impressive for such a commercial brew.  Better than any BMC product..
Surpringly hoppy flavor and aroma for a canned beer.  Again, better with sushi than on its own.

01.11.05  Cooler 22oz can than the Premium: same shape but with golden grainy things on it.  Slightly darker than pale yellow with no visible eff; monster white head is rocky and brainy as it fades to a decent film and laces in stucco patterns on the glass.  Aroma is grassy and clean with clear grain notes and peppery hops.  Yeasty.  Full bodied for such a pale brew, the beer is sweet and lithe as it smoothly coats the palate.  Mild malt flavors with a nice grassy hop character.  This is worlds better than the ’premium draft’, and just as unexpected.

From a 22 oz. can - it poured a dark yellow color with an impressive, frothy white head.  It’s got a mild, sweet malt aroma, maybe a bit grassy.  The flavor is good clean malt (no adjuncts) with a nice balance in the hops.  Clean, crisp finish.  Nothing special, but not bad.

Aluminum can from Seafood City Market: Poured a golden elixir with a thick fluffy formation of head which eventually retreated back down. Aroma is strong with grains and sweet malts that overwhelm the sensory glands of my nose and for some obvious reasons make me crave sushi, wasabi and ginger being stuffed down my mouth as I gulp this down. The drink is well balanced considering this was an all malt beer and that it actually tasted like it was from Sapporo. Okay beer for the price and I would say it definitely passes most American and Mexican made malt liquor beers. 

1st rating- December 6, 2004 (Can )Golden color just lile the bottom of the can pictures.  Foam and fluffy head.  Poor flavor of malt and not a good beer on its own.  Had to stop by the liquor store and pick up a Japanesse beer to go with my tempura sushi roll.

Poured clear yellow with a white head.  Pale lager aroma.  Taste was somewhat sweet with little hop or malt.  Clean, non-existent finish.  Watery body.  Goes down easy, but nothing special.  Can’t tell the difference between this and regular Sapporo.
thought maybe with the "reserve" label it might be something  a little more interesting than the standard sapporo. Thin, watery, cardboard.. bleh..

Big ol’ bottle.  This is okay, but it goes much better with a shot of sake dropped in your glass.  (Sake Bomb!!!!)  Overall, nothing special but not disgusting.  Hints of rice, barley and weak hops make this one an expensive version of cheap American swill.
big ol can. a nice drink... wish i was eating some suchi to go with it... but nothing too interesting going on.

Nice looking can at least.  Sweet malt aroma.  The flavor was also rather sweet, with a note of honey.  In the background, there was a very faint floral hop note.  Not bad, but just not that good either.

I’ll rate this one as an everyday walking around beer. I wouldn’t dink this on a special occassion but it’s quite drinkable as an everyday beer. Nothing offensive about it. Actually has some flavor which a lot of lagers don’t seem to have.
Decent for a Euro style Japanese beer.  The head was less than I expected.  Quite smooth despite its other ho-hum qualities.  Although not outstanding, it was still a well above average beer.

Japanese beer using the German Purity Law? It sounds like these two might be hatching something....Nothing like Germans and purity...Anyways, onto the beer.  For a lager its ok.  Quickly dissipating frothy soap head over yellow amber color.  Im just drinking this too pad the stats, not because I actually wanted it. Oh well, it has a cool looking can..  #200 BABY!
Pretty refreshing with a nice kick.  It certainly does taste great at a Japanese restaurant, but I am not sure who buys this stuff for home consumption.
Not band. Just kinda bland. You can drink it. Even though it came in a can, it still has kind of a skunky/DMS note.
Pours gold with a big foamy white head. Has a strong malt grain flavor to it, with a bit of metallic twang. Somewhat bitter aftertaste. Unspectacular.

A PERFECT beer!!  Besides Tsingtao beer which I need to support..hehe  A light golden color look.  Makes me feel rich when I consume it.  Fruity, honey sweet, floral, slight maltiness, some bitterness at the end.  Maan this brew is complex!!  Nice long ass bubble action in my crystal glass.  Japanese sure knows how to make good beer!!  I luv it!!  Highly recommended!!  A+++ to E=mc2 to infinity.

(22oz can) First off, I find it hard to believe that I’m drinking a beer from a can -- I mean, it’s a cool looking can, but it explicitly says it’s a "Malt Liquor."  Big white foamy head atop a crystal clear straw body.  Aroma is mild sweet, grassy, cereal.  Taste is mild sweet, cereal up top, before turning mildly bitter grassy mid-tongue and into the swallow.  Watery body.

This is great, and perhaps even better than regular Sapporo.  A great session beer that you can just sit there and drink all night and feel great.  Pours a really light golden color, that like in other ratings looks slightly like a champagne.  Lots of carbonation, fruity and sweet.  Has a tasty malt character, with just a bit of hoppiness in the finish.

Kanbai! This bullet train can with 1" thick walls pours a clear golden yellow with a gargantuan yet quickly dissipating rocky white. Aroma contains champagne, apple, grains, cereal. Not as much carbonation in the body as I expected. Initial flavor is not too bad. Slightly watery overall, but not bad for the style. The finish is sticky sweet, corn syrupy at times, dry, adjuncts come out. Overall its drinkable, especially considering that I could not think of a better lager that comes in cans. In summation,and probably incorrect Nihongo: Sapporo (no yoyaku) no biiru wa totemo omoshiroikuarimasen.
this is some good stuff. goes down smooth and has a good flavor. id reccommend this to anyone
Can: This is pretty good. Has more flavor than the regular Sapporo. A bit hoppy, and goes down fairly easy.

Rerate - had in the big 650 ml bottle - rare find at the local pub - not quite as good - very corny, mineral water aroma, pasty, corny mouthfeel. . Much better in the can. Original 3.1 Big 650 ml can  - pleasantly surprised - does not excel in any one area - but all around very drinkable. Fluffy white head with good lacing that sticks around a while, dark yellow, slightly murky appearance - good bubble action. Fresh, slightly fruity aroma, like a muted APA. Slightly hoppy and fruity flavor with a pleasant mouthfeel. Has a bit of honey sweetness to it as well. Not as dry as most Japanese beers. Probably the best of the few Japanese beers I have had to date.

Bottle pours dark straw with a minor fizzy white head.   Carbonation is light, lacing seems good.   Aroma is of malts and unsweetened pears.   Taste is much the same.   Sweet finish, crisp, definately a light, easy to drink lager.   Slight hop bitterness in the aftertaste.   I've always had a soft spot for Japanese lagers for some reason, being some of the first beers I got into.

Pours a clear golden color with a attractive medium sized bright white head.  Aroma is not too bad actually, nice malty flower smells.  Flavor is nothing assertive and is  somewhat pleasant with a  very clean sweetness with a slight hop finish.  Thin body.  A decent lager.
The japanese brews are not bad, they go great with the food. the flavor is not strong. this one has a little more going on on the back end than some of its counterparts.

Clear, straw-colored lager with a medium-sized, fizzy, white head.
Malty, floral aroma.
Thin flavor. Light-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish. Boring.
Clear pale yellow with a huge rocky white head.  Sweet malts with a touch of plastic in the nose.  Sweet corny taste, watery texture.  Stale ending.  This could be worse.
Clear gold pour, smallish head. Aroma is typical macro-lagerish, adjunct laden flavor, overcarbonated.
it's from japan, ok!  don't go japanese for beer.  ok appearance.  weak on flavor, no character.  hey, this was for taste testing!
Marginally better than regular Sapporo. Golden color, fizzy. Sweet, corny, and light. Not much fun.

OK saw this can beside the horrid Sapporo Draft ( terrible IMO)..and was feeling like a review and this was one of the very few beers in the store I ahd not "done"..so here goes 
Surprisingly it poured a quite attractive beer in the glass..nice semi dark golden colour with a nice creamy white head..no artificial looking carbonation strings like in the Draft.
Smell is also quite attractive fresh and malty..with very very faint floral hops.
Taste is sort of toasted malts..and creaminess..some tiny spiciness..actually not at all bad.
Average on the palate.
Actually quite a drinkable beer..not bad at all..500% better than the Draft..but not worth the premium price.

The Quintessential lager gold color on the pour, planetary sized head, could be because I dropped the can twice, head is bright white, frothy in texture with the lace a thin white curtain to seal off the glass. Archetypal lager clean and crisp malt laden nose, sweet malt start, top is light in feel. Finish is crisply acidic and the hops apropos to the style, an average beer at best.

Light golden with a fizzy white head. Bread dough aroma, with only a hint of hops. Sweet start, with flavors of cream of rice, for lack of a better grain description. Light floral bittering hops later in the gulp. Very fizzy in the mouth.

Hey, it was on sale.  Actually it was better then the last beer I had.  You know, it's bad when you take a month off from drinking, and your drunk after one beer.  I have some work to do to get back into drinking shape!!!

Pale gold. No head. Smells a little bitter, malty. A little more bitter than the Sapporo & has a little more flavor but isn't its superior. Very metallic out of the can. A lot of beer for the price. Great cans but not the best.
Lighter amber color, small quick disappearing head, very light slightly friuty aroma,Slight sweet sour malt taste, doesn't seem to complex, no bitter aftertaste

From the can, this looks just like their "Original" except a little lighter yellow versus orange.  It has the expected macro airy aroma.  The flavor is smooth to a fault, almost flat.  It's malty, to be sure, but I like this better than the Original.
Better than the Sapporo Draft in a can, but the main flavor still tastes like metal. Kind of harsh. Has some grainy and fruity sweetness to it.

This beer pours a plain yellow color with a small white head that quickly disappears and no lacing on the glass.  The aroma is a little malty, a little wheaty, but very plain in actuality.  The flavor is very plain and uninteresting.  Obviously a mass-produced beer, but for some reason, the Reserve is not as tasty as the regular Sapporo.  Who knows.

From a can, beer pours (in Chimay glass) an applejiuce (piss, read 'urine')-golden color with virgin-white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is strong straw, grass, vegetal.  Flavor is strong straw, grass with an overpowering disgusting bitter aftertaste.  Drainpour.  Terrible, terrible, disgusting.  A shame to the name 'beer'.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.

Better than the typical mass produced lager, for whatever that is worth. Color is not bad, slightly darker and fuller looking than its brethern. Very foamy head. Tastes metallic and finishes even more metallic.

Nice gold color, uneven white head.  Pleasantly sweet malts - medium bodied.  Finish is clean then bitter and aluminum (from the can? or is it a psycological effect?)  The finish got better as it warmed

Not much aroma... smells like yellow beer.  The head is white and foamy.The malt wants to be tasted but it is overridden by a bitter flavor... maybe the can?  The word to describe this beer overall is: Metallic.

Pale golden copper hue.  Thick foamy white head.  Grainy alcohol nose.  Smells like Old English or some crap.  Really watery, nasty grain, light metal, light bodied, finishes with a real crappy bitterness.  Kinda like heineken out of a can.
Just OK.  Kind of maltier version of American lager.  There's realy not much more to say about this, except that is very average.  Good but average.

Specimen colored, but cool can.  Sapporo continues to impress with their packaging. So-so to better-than-average.  Fairly dry, moderately hoppy.  Tangy hop and peppery finish, which clings a little too much.

Huge twisted can for 99¢.  Poured ultra-fizzy and the head ran over and over, spilling everywhere. Smells much like any US macro-swill (corn, newspaper, metallic, grass) but has a much fuller taste.  The grassiness was nice, and the grainy, ricy, malty middle wasn't offensive, as most are.  Huge can for under a buck if you are looking for such a thing (I was).
Yellow beer with a nice head.  Somewhat metallic smelling.  Flavor slightly sweet with hints of metal towards the middle.  SOmewhat watery and weak.  Pretty non-descript, but decent.

Optimistic about this all malt pale lager, but the appearance was not very promising, a faded inconsistently pissy gold with a foaming but rapidly fading head.  Light hint of herbs and spicy hops in the nose, a touch of buttery malts.  Hints at a weakish but true pilsner.  Perhaps some DMS vegetal notes skirting the edges of the nose.  Pretty bland though, and flattish.  Dead on the tongue.  Slickly sweet because it really lacks bittering hops, and not much flavoring hops either.  Feels like a weak malt liquor in the end.
Slightly skunky, corn nose, yellow, fizzy. Has somewhat of a hop kick at the finish but mild. Uneventful.

Nose of pine resin, perfume, hints of smoke, charcoal, fruit and flowers.  Not exactly appealing, not exactly offensive.  The brew pours a cloudy light honey amber.  The large fluffy white head has no lacing and is mostly diminishing.  The brew starts neutral with a sweet middle that gets sweeter at the finish.  The light and creamy body is lively to the point of being almost fizzy with a metallic stickiness at the finish.  Not something I would buy again.  It clashes with my tastes.
Hokkaido dortmunder. Not bad, but lacks a certain something.................

Light gold color, large head. A lighter bodied lager style beer. Nice mild hops. Milder malts with some sweetness. Good balance. Nice full flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Smooth taste. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Clear light yellow, fizzy, foamy head, grainy aroma, metallic taste.........
Ouch.  The alcohol really shines through on this one.  Not my thing at all.  It seems heavily adjunct-laden and nasty.
